ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course helped introduce me to modern Western philosophy.
Knowledge of the arc of modern philosophy; ability to reconstruct complex philosophical arguments logically and precisely
My philosophical sophistication was improved. I gained knowledge into analytic and metaphysical philosophy that was previously unknown to me.
I learned about philosophy. The readings were generally interesting.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was immensely harmed by a poor discussion section in which the professor often treated the class like a lecture. Student discussion and focus on assigned reading was rare. This course would be far better with a focus on student discussion and close adherence to the overall DS syllabus.
The seminar was a bit lackluster, I think it could be made more lively. The lectures would perhaps be more effective if recorded as well.
The material was interesting. Everything else was very, very bad.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would not, take an intro philosophy course or an intro modern philosophy/intellectual thought course.

Yes --- having a generally understanding of modern philosophy is helpful. Frankly, though, spring philosophy was my least favorite of the six DS classes. The readings are very challenging (particularly Kant and Fichte). Very hard to enjoy the course and get a lot out of it without a great professor who will explain the complicated arguments. In other DS courses (like literature, and even fall philosophy), the texts speak for themselves. That being said, with a good professor (or a lot of independent work outside of class), spring philosophy can be very rewarding. Mastering Kant's argument for transcendental idealism is as exciting as it is essential.
DS is great, and you have to take philosophy, so yeah, I'd recommend it.
